awd_abstract_narration:
Plants are essential for all life on earth: they provide the oxygen we breathe, medicines, raw materials for industry and construction, fuel, nutrition, and food. Globally, 62% of harvested crop is used for human food, 3% to produce seeds for replanting, bioenergy, and industrial products, and 35% for animal feed. The priority goals of the United Nations include "End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture". This is not a trivial goal as plants are quite literally "rooted to the spot" and cannot escape adverse conditions. It is essential to understand how plants sense environmental changes, signal these changes to other parts of the plant and adjust development accordingly. Lipids are oil and fat-soluble molecules that play an important role in plant and animal development and serve as signals for changing environmental conditions. As a result, understanding the function of plant lipids and the mechanism of their transport will serve not only the scientific understanding of plant developmental processes but will also translate into tangible improvements of food sustainability and quality:
 - Understanding how lipids affect plant growth and seed and fruit development will lead to higher yields and more food.
 - Understanding how lipids affect plant survival in changing environments (cold, freezing, drought, nutrient-deficient soil, insect feeding etc.) will reduce crop losses. 

Lipids are essential components of plants. They provide energy for metabolic processes, are membrane components, and serve as intracellular signals. Simple lipids such as oxylipins are long-distance signals of biotic stress suggesting other lipids function as systemic signals as well. Given the fundamental importance of mobile signals for the coordination of abiotic stress and development, and thus for plant survival and food security, it is imperative to unequivocally demonstrate the existence of long-distance phospholipid-signaling and its components.  The PI's lab has identified the lipid phosphatidic acid (PA) and a PA-binding protein (PLAFP) in phloem exudates and proposed that phloem lipid-binding proteins, particularly PLAFP and PA act in development and in long-distance signaling in response to environmental stress.  To test this hypothesis, the lab will
 - Investigate localization and movement of the protein PLAFP using a combination of transgenic approaches, grafting, western blot, confocal microscopy, immunogold labeling and NightOWL imaging.
 - Monitor lipid movement in wild type, PLAFP-overexpression and PLAFP knock-down plants. MS will confirm the identity of the radiolabeled mobile compound.
 - Determine binding mechanisms and specificity of the PLAFP-PA complex and its movement using a combination of a "Red-Light-ON" optogenetic switch with a novel FRET approach that visualizes protein-lipid interaction in vitro and in-planta. Once established this system will provide a tool to study protein-ligand interactions in any system.
The work will be assisted by a postdoctoral researcher, a graduate student, and an undergraduate. They will be able to participate in an international collaboration/exchange with the Heinrich-Heine University Duesseldorf, Germany.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Phospholipids (PLs) are essential membrane components but can function as signals as well. In both functions they are essential for plant development, pathogen response and adaptation to different environmental conditions.

Intellectual merit:

We identified several lipids and lipid-binding proteins that are produced in response to abiotic stress. One of those proteins, PLAFP (phloem lipid-associated family protein) binds the lipid PA (phosphatidic acid) that is a known intracellular signal for biotic and abiotic stress. As part of this grant research we have shown that both, protein and lipid, are present in the plant vasculature and, hence, could function as long-distance signals. Indeed, modulation of the amount of protein also affects the amount of PA detected in the phloem. In addition, plants overexpressing PLAFP establish their root system faster and grow larger, suggesting an important role in seedling establishment and possibly drought tolerance.

We used a novel gene-regulation system employing a promoter that is turned on by red light and off by blue light. As a result, gene expression is also turned off in the dark and in white light. This allowed us to show that, if a plant is kept in white light and a single leaf is exposed to red light, the protein is not only produced in that single leaf but also moves to other leaves. Our next step will be to examine if protein and lipid move together. This tool can now be used by the scientific community to examnine if a protein (or  RNA) are phloem mobile and to test there function by using the light induction for spacio-temporal control.

A two-pronged approach was employed to study protein-lipid interaction: 1) protein-lipid overlays and tryptophan fluorescence quenching established the specificity and binding constants for PLAFP-PA interaction. 2) Computational alignments of PLAFP homologues suggested several putative interaction sites. Molecular dynamic simulation based thermodynamics-based modeling elucidated the orientation of the protein along the plasma membrane and narrowed down the candidates for lipid binding sites. It also suggested that the protein may act by scanning along the membrane until it reaches the lipid ligand PA and then opening the aperture between two loops and picking up the lipid in a tweezer like mechanism. This model can now be tested using the point-mutation mutants generated as part of this project.

Broader impacts:

The project was used to train four undergraduate students (Briaunna Murray/african-american female, Dani Aguirre-Boyd/hispanic female, Carson Polakowski/caucasian femal, Rylee Sokoloski/caukasian female), one postbac BRTP student (Evan Kurtz/caucasian male), one postbac student (Kimani Hamilton-Wray/african american male) and one graduate student (Amanda Koenig/caucasian female). Amanda participated in an exchange visit with our collaborators at the Heinrich-Heine University in Duesseldorf (HHUD), Germany and presented her work at several international (ISPL2018), national (GRC 2019; ASPB2020 &2021) and local meetings (MWASPB 2018/2019; NEXTplant at MSU 2021).Briaunna also attended one MWASPB meeting. For the others, sadly, there were no meetings due to COVID. Dani and Rylee both attended our exchange program with HHUD. While this is not an explicit part of the grant, their work in my lab triggered their interest in what I believe is a great educational, cultural and scientific experience for undergrads.

The method we developed to use for light-dependent spatio-temporal control of gene expression can now be used as a tool to study protein and mRNA mobility by other plant researchers as well. 

Our data suggest that PLAFP overexpression leads to more efficient seedling establishment and drought tolerance. Hence, further study of this protein and its interaction with PA could lead to strategies for generating plants that can either grow in more marginal areas or to a reduce in water use. Both aspects have the potential to increase food security.
